title: 109_s740
content: The "Start Healthy, Stay Healthy Act of 2005" allows states to expand Medicaid and SCHIP coverage for certain pregnant women. The "Start Healthy, Stay Healthy Act of 2005" permits states to broaden Medicaid and SCHIP coverage for specific pregnant women by amending certain sections of the Social Security Act. The "Start Healthy, Stay Healthy Act of 2005" allows states to expand Medicaid and SCHIP coverage for pregnant women meeting specific conditions, including those with income levels exceeding the poverty line but not exceeding the income eligibility level for targeted low-income children under title XXI. The "Start Healthy, Stay Healthy Act of 2005" sets conditions for states regarding coverage for pregnant women, ensuring that higher-income pregnant women are not excluded from coverage while also maintaining income eligibility levels specified in the state plan as of January 1, 2005. The "Start Healthy, Stay Healthy Act of 2005" ensures coverage for pregnant women, including higher-income individuals, without excluding them based on income eligibility levels specified in the state plan as of January 1, 2005. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding payment from title xxi allotment for Medicaid expansion costs and the definition of poverty line. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding Medicaid, including eligibility of newborns and application of qualified entities for presumptive eligibility for pregnant women. Amendments to the Social Security Act include expanding the definition of "qualified provider" to include qualified entities as defined in section 1920A(b)(3) and adding coverage for pregnant women under Title XXI of the Act. Optional coverage of targeted low-income pregnant women under Title XXI of the Social Security Act. Optional coverage of pregnancy-related assistance for targeted low-income pregnant women can be provided by a State through an amendment to its State child health plan under section 2102, subject to meeting certain conditions. Pregnancy-related assistance includes services related to pregnancy, such as prenatal, delivery, and postpartum services, as well as other related conditions. The term 'targeted low-income pregnant woman' refers to a woman during pregnancy and up to 60 days after giving birth, whose family income meets specific criteria to be eligible for medical assistance under title XIX. The text discusses eligibility criteria for targeted low-income pregnant women under the State child health plan, including references to terms and special rules for coverage of pregnancy-related assistance. The text outlines special rules for coverage of pregnancy-related assistance under the State child health plan, including references to pregnant women as children for eligibility purposes and no exclusion of benefits based on preexisting conditions. Automatic Enrollment for Children Born to Women Receiving Pregnancy-Related Assistance: If a child is born to a targeted low-income pregnant woman receiving assistance under this section, the child is deemed to have applied for child health assistance under the State plan or medical assistance under title. Children born to women receiving pregnancy-related assistance are automatically enrolled in child health or medical assistance under the State plan until the child turns 1 year old. The mother's identification number also serves as the child's during this period. Additional allotments are provided for coverage of pregnant women under the Social Security Act. Additional allotments of $200,000,000 are appropriated for fiscal years 2006 and 2007 to provide coverage for pregnant women under the State child health plan approved under the Social Security Act. The text chunk describes the proportion of allotments for states and commonwealths/territories under subsections (b) and (c) respectively, for a fiscal year. The text chunk outlines the conditions for additional allotments provided to states for child health assistance and pregnancy-related assistance for low-income individuals. No payments can be made unless the state offers pregnancy-related assistance for low-income pregnant women. The text chunk discusses adjustments to income levels for families under the Social Security Act. Presumptive eligibility under title xxi is also mentioned. The text chunk discusses amendments to presumptive eligibility under title xxi of the Social Security Act, specifically related to sections 1920 and 1920A. It also includes an exception for presumptive eligibility expenditures from the limitation on administrative expenses. The text chunk discusses amendments to title xxi of the Social Security Act, specifically related to pregnancy-related services and no waiting period. Amendments to the Social Security Act eliminate waiting periods for targeted low-income pregnant women receiving services, effective October 1, 2005. Amendments to the Social Security Act eliminate waiting periods for targeted low-income pregnant women receiving services, effective October 1, 2005. Coordination with the Maternal and Child Health Program is required. Amendments to the Social Security Act require consultation and coordination with the State's program under title V for various operations and activities. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Medicaid Act. Amendments to the Social Security Act require consultation and coordination with the State's program under title V for various operations and activities, including outreach, enrollment, benefits, services, service delivery standards, public health, social service agency relationships, quality assurance, and data reporting. The amendments take effect on January 1, 2006. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN SCHIP INCOME ELIGIBILITY. Amends the Social Security Act to increase the income eligibility threshold for low-income children from 200 to 250. Effective starting fiscal year 2006.
